awd_titl_txt: Stability of shocks and layers in Fluid Mechanics and related problems
awd_abstract_narration:
The main part of the project concerns the study of dramatic behaviors in fluid mechanics known as shocks.  A typical example, in oceanography, is the propagation of a tsunami.  Understanding flows with shocks is of particular importance for engineering and industry.  The investigator studies the stability of such structures using state of the art mathematical tools.  The project focuses on these specific goals: (1) Advance the knowledge of physical systems that are of fundamental importance in engineering, meteorology, medicine, or natural disasters, such as flooding and tsunamis; (2) Develop powerful mathematical tools, based on the theory of nonlinear partial differential equations, that can be used to study these systems. Graduate students are involved in the work of the project, which provides good opportunities for training junior researchers in mathematical analysis and physical modeling.

The investigator studies the stability of discontinuous solutions in compressible fluid mechanics, known as shocks.  They are linked to intriguing behaviors of fluids, especially in supersonic flows.  This project advances the understanding of these phenomena.  A special emphasis is on the study of asymptotic limits from viscous models such as compressible Navier-Stokes equations, or from kinetic models.  These problems involve the study of layers subject to large perturbations.  The investigator also studies the existence and properties of solutions to related models, such as compressible Navier-Stokes equations with degenerated viscosities, or nonlinear nonhomogeneous kinetic equations.  For this purpose, the investigator uses and develops deep analysis tools, such as the De Giorgi method and the relative entropy method.

por.por_cntn:
The main scientific goal of this project was to develop new powerful analytical tools to study the behavior of fluids far from smooth or equilibrium settings. The project has been very successful.

 A first part  was dedicated to the  study of  the stability of discontinuous patterns in compressible inviscid fluid mechanics. A powerful method, the a-contraction theory with shifts, was further developed to obtain the first improvement in the last two decades on the uniqueness theory for general solutions to conservation laws. In this project, the stability of discontinuous traveling waves, as shocks, have been systematically studied as inviscid limit of traveling waves of  slightly viscous flows at high Reynolds number. The result shows surprisingly strong stability properties, uniform with respect to the Reynolds number. In a second part, the project pioneered the use of tools from the elliptic  theory to study regularization effects for the kinetic theory, which describes flows far from the thermodynamical equilibrium.  Finally, a third party focused on the construction of global solutions to compressible Navier-Stokes equations with degenerate viscosities. 

 This project offered excellent opportunities to train a  new generation of mathematicians in a fertile scientific environment. All the junior collaborators involved in the project and going on the job market got prestigious positions in academia.
